description:
Collaboration with Tsuburaya Productions.

Yuta Hibiki awakens with amnesia and the ability see things that others cannot. He first encounters a Gridman in the reflection of his friend Rikka Takarada's computer and it tells him to "Remember his calling," but Yuta doesn't understand what this means. Later, in the distance, he sees an extremely large monster but it doesn't move. It's only when Yuta gets to school that the two sightings make sense: a monster attacks and the hero Yuta saw in the computer screen pulls him within the computer and transforms Yuta into a giant hero named Gridman.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Tokusatsu
tags.description: Prominently features elements that resemble special effects in Japanese live-action shows

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Superhero
tags.description: Prominently features super-powered humans who aim to serve the greater good.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Hikikomori
tags.description: Prominently features a character who withdraws from social life, often seeking extreme isolation.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Yandere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is obsessively in love with another, to the point of acting deranged or violent.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Mixed Media
tags.description: Features a combination of different media and animation techniques. Often seen with puppetry, textiles, live action footage, stop motion, and more. This does not include works with normal usage of CGI in their production.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Villainess
tags.description: Centers around or prominently features a villainous noble lady.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

name.native: サムライ・キャリバー

node.description:
Akira Amemiya is an animator and up-and-coming director best known for directing [SSSS.GRIDMAN](https://anilist.co/anime/99424/SSSSGRIDMAN) and being Studio Trigger founder [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/Hiroyuki-Imaishi)'s protege. Amemiya's [animation and directing](https://blog.sakugabooru.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/mini-imaishi.mp4) is very similar to Imaishi's yet is less chaotic and contains more 'retro' devices like impact frames and multi-tonal shading, drawing a lot of inspiration from [Masami Obari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/Masami-Obari). For these reasons he was frequently typecasted for old school pose-heavy mecha combat.

Amemiya is a nerdy director whose anime often heavily references other series and artists he loves, sometimes even replicating Obari's [animation sequences](https://blog.sakugabooru.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/dangaioh2.mp4) and [layouts](https://i.imgur.com/nTRdM4K.jpg), [Transformer](https://twitter.com/SSS_SGRID/status/1051063114022572033)'s color designs, and Hideaki Anno's [establishing shots](https://blog.sakugabooru.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/welcome-to-the-anno-class.jpg) as well as long-lingering framing. Amemiya called Anno's [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/Evangelion/) his [favorite series before](https://i.imgur.com/nEYK186.png). Between his ode-heavy artistry he interjects personality with [subtle details](https://blog.sakugabooru.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/what-kind-of-brand-is-TOMATO-LIFE-tho.jpg), visual gags, and repurposing tonally contrasting homages into a different context.

Amemiya graduated from Tokyo University of Technology and was part of the university's anime research society. During his time there he became heavily influenced by Osaka University's anime research club [Group CAS](https://twitter.com/group_cas). At the time [Toshiyuki Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/107357/Toshiyuki-Satou) was part of the group, while [Ikehata Hiroshi](https://anilist.co/staff/120505/Ikehata-Hiroshi) visited regularly. After a bit of indie work Amemiya joined studio Gainax and climbed up the hierarchy: from clean-up to animation direction, onto storyboarding and episode directing, until after joining studio Trigger and co-directing Kill la Kill finally having the credentials to debut with his own series.

He is married to animator [Megumi Kouno](https://anilist.co/staff/120602/Megumi-Kouno).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dinahasegawa)

Hasegawa Keiichi was a secondary writer on Kamen Rider W, Kamen Rider Fourze, Kamen Rider Drive and Kamen Rider Ghost. He is more known for his work on the Ultra Series, having written for every Ultraman series produced since Tiga (except for Ultraman Max), he has written more material for the franchise than any other writer.

He also played a drunken man in Kamen Rider W Returns: Kamen Rider Accel.

(Source: Kamen Rider Wiki)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/2215146188)

Married to [Satomi Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/142387/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/58853969)
Mitsuyoshi Yamamoto does photography.
Affiliated with [Graphinica](https://anilist.co/studio/894/Graphinica).

__Agency:__ I'm Enterprise

[Website](http://uchidamaaya.jp/) | [Profile](https://www.imenterprise.jp/profile.php?id=26) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/maaya_taso) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/uchidamaayataso/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJFEXIRB6DP_2FQJzv7pbXg)

Maaya Uchida is a Japanese actress, voice actress and singer who works for I'm Enterprise. She is [Yuuma Uchida](https://anilist.co/staff/119617/)'s older sister.

**Awards:**
- She won the Best New Actress Award at the 8th Seiyuu Awards, for her role as [Hajime Ichinose](https://anilist.co/character/85153/).

**Non anime roles:**
- [Fischl](https://anilist.co/character/209685/Fischl) - Genshin Impact (VG)
- [Ichihime](https://anilist.co/character/200348/Ichihime) - Mahjong Soul (VG)
- Pure Vanilla Cookie - Cookie Run: Kingdom (VG)
- Admi - Goddess of Victory: Nikke (VG)
- Epinel - Goddess of Victory: Nikke (VG)
- Ms. NewBabel - Reverse: 1999 (VG)
- Gretel - SINoAlice (VG)
- Sakura - Shinobi Nightmare (VG)
- Kanami - Strinova (VG)
- S-Sha - Megadimension Neptunia VII (VG)
- Zero - Drakengard 3 (VG)
- Hiroyo Hakase - Hikōnin Sentai Akibaranger (Super Sentai)

__[Website](http://www.oxt-music.com/)__

__Formed:__ 2013
__Genres:__ Rock (Digital Rock), J-POP, Anison

__Introduction:__
OxT is a Japanese duo consisting of Masayoshi Ooishi and Tomohiro Oshima (better known as Tom-H@ck), who are under record labels Pony Canyon and KADOKAWA, affiliated with FMF Corporation. They originally collaborated under the name Tom-H@ck ft. Masayoshi Ooishi, but was later changed in 2015 to OxT when they went from a collaboration to a unit.

__Biography:__
The duo first came to life when Masayoshi was selected during an audition for the anime "Ace of Diamond", where Tom-H@ck was in-charge of the opening theme song. In a recording session, they eventually landed on a song titled "GO EXCEED!!", which Masayoshi performed and Tomohiro produced.

After this appearance, they would go on for about a year and a half under the name "Tom-H@ck. featuring Masayoshi Ooishi", before Tomohiro fronted to Masayoshi about how the collaboration didn't feel quite right with him only credited as a featuring artist. As a continuation of this, and during their rise of popularity, Tomohiro made a suggestion to Masayoshi asking if they should start a unit, which Masayoshi responded that he always intended to do so. The unit was officially announced under the name OxT on January 18, 2015.

__Members:__
- [Masayoshi Ooishi](https://anilist.co/staff/123728) (大石昌良, オーイシマサヨシ) – vocalist, in-charge of lyrics, composition and arrangement
- [Tomohiro Oshima](https://anilist.co/staff/107596) (大嶋文博, Tom-H@ck) – vocalist, in-charge of composition and arrangement

(Source: [Wikipedia](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/OxT), edited)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ebisu1984)

Originating from [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). Currently freelance with a seat at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/58853969)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)

A prominent anime creator and one of the founders of studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

While still in university, Maeda was part of a manga club together with [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/), during which both of them got invited to participate on [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and [Daicon IV](https://anilist.co/anime/121664/). This brought Maeda enough recognition to get invited on the production of [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/), and the subseqeunt late '80s [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) films. He also worked on [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s projects during this time.

In 1992, after having completely cut ties with Ghibli due to differences in working methods, Maeda founded Gonzo together with [Shinji Higuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/107646/), [Hiroshi Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97308/) and [Shouji Murahama](https://anilist.co/staff/119708/), who were Gainax employees he had previously worked with on [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). At Gonzo he debuted as a director in 1998 with [Blue Submarine No.6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/).

In 2004, Maeda directed [Gankutsuou](https://anilist.co/anime/239/), an adaptation of an 1844 novel, The Count of Monte Cristo, by [Alexandre Dumas](https://anilist.co/staff/102535/). Initially Maeda wanted to adapt an Alfred Bester novel, The Stars My Destination, but was rejected by the novel's copyright holders after proposing the numerous changes he wanted to make to the original narrative. He then searched for another work he could adapt into a science fiction setting and ended up going with The Count of Monte Cristo. The series was praised by Western critics and received multiple international accolades.

Called one of the most imaginative visualists in anime by Helen McCarthy, a British anime reference book author.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Known to have been a close friend of [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s before his passing.
